Hi Craig,

It looks good, but why don't you test at the level of the MDB itself ?
Use EasyMock to create a mock of the JMS Message object (for the
onMessage() method) and off you go ... That's what I'm doing and it
works real fine.

Thus I don't incur the penalty of copying information from a Message
object to my own format (hey, why reinvent the wheel ? :-)). The same
principle could apply to ResultSet that you get from the DB.

Cheers,
-Vincent

> Subject: RE: [junit] EJB Testing Strategies
> 
> > What strategies have people successfully employed for testing
> > business/workflow methods of a stateless session bean that
> > has CMP entity beans at the back-end ?
> 
> <broken-record>
> If you face difficulty in testing your application, J2EE or otherwise,
> consider refactoring to a design more suitable to testing.  (Of
course,
> it's advisable to have some tests to support your refactoring).
> </borken-record>
> 
> Thus, I design EJBs such that they almost exclusively rely on one or
> more non-EJB classes to do work.  For example, my latest component
> includes a message-driven bean (MDB).  The MDB instantiates a few
> objects that together parse the message (XMLReader, ContentHandler,
> etc.).  A Map of parsed values is then obtained from the
ContentHandler.
> This Map is passed to an object that interprets the contents of the
Map
> and performs some work.  The results of the work are captured in a
> result object that acts as a Collecting Parameter (a design pattern
from
> _Smalltalk Best Practices_ by Kent Beck, I believe).  The result
object
> is passed to a communicator object whose job it is to create a
response
> message and send it.  Thus, I have, for example, ResultTestCase,
> CommunicatorTestCase, etc.  Finally, I'm confident that these classes
> will perform as expected when the MDB uses them.
> 
> Good luck,
> Craig
